p: Pliny the Elder described the leaves of silphion as: “The leaves of this plant were known as “maspetum,” and bore considerable resemblance to parsley” in his “Natural History” [ 13]. The leaf segments of Ferula drudeana are not as broad as the typical parsley leaf segment. This difference may be due to the ecological transformation of F. drudeana in its current location over the 2000 years of growth cycles, and perhaps, F. drudeana is an ecotype of the silphion plant. An alternate explanation of this discrepancy could be due to the morphological variations of basal leaf segments of Ferula species; there are several examples of such variations known from other Ferula species, such as F. tingitana L. and F. elaeochytris Korovin [ 27, 28].
